message.content: We refer to CDC guidelines on newborn care for help. Breast milk does not contain enough Vitamin D and newborns can also have low Vitamin K levels. Therefore, it is recommended to give Vitamin D and Vitamin K supplements to breastfed newborns, even if they receive no other routine medical care. Folic acid is important for pregnant women to take during pregnancy but is not necessary for newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breast milk is a great source of nutrition for infants, but it may not provide enough Vitamin K and Vitamin D. Vitamin K is important for blood clotting, and newborns are at risk of developing bleeding disorders if their levels are low. Vitamin D is important for bone health and immune system function. Therefore, newborns should receive both Vitamin K and Vitamin D supplements, especially if they are not receiving routine medical care. Folic acid is important during pregnancy to prevent birth defects but is not necessary for the newborn's nutrition.

We consult medical guidelines for infant nutrition for help. Breast milk provides optimal nutrition for infants, but it may not supply sufficient amounts of vitamin K and vitamin D. Therefore, both vitamin K and vitamin D supplementation are recommended for breastfed newborns. Vitamin K supplementation is particularly important to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Vitamin D supplementation is important for bone health and can prevent rickets. It is important to note that this recommendation may vary depending on location, season, and other factors, so it is best to consult with a healthcare provider for individualized recommendations. Folic acid is not typically recommended for newborns but is important for pregnant women to take to prevent birth defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breast milk provides most of the nutritional needs for a newborn, but vitamin K and vitamin D are recommended to be given as supplements in the first few months. Vitamin K is important for blood clotting, and deficiency can lead to bleeding disorders. Vitamin D is important for calcium absorption and bone growth, and deficiency can lead to rickets. Folic acid is not specifically required for a breast-fed newborn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breast milk is a good source of nutrition for newborns, but they still need certain vitamins that may not be present in sufficient amounts in breast milk. Vitamin K is important for blood clotting and is typically given to newborns intramuscularly shortly after birth. Vitamin D is important for bone health and can be given to newborns as drops. Both are recommended for newborns, especially if they are not receiving routine medical care and vaccinations. Folic acid is important for the mother during pregnancy but is not typically given to newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin K is given to newborns to prevent bleeding, and Vitamin D is important for bone health and immune system function. Both vitamins are typically given to newborns in the hospital, but if the child was born at home and is not receiving routine medical care, it is important to give both vitamins to ensure that the child's nutritional needs are met. Folic acid is not typically necessary for newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin K is commonly given to newborns to prevent bleeding disorders, especially if the child was born at home. Vitamin D is also important for newborns as breast milk has low levels of it. Therefore, both vitamin K and vitamin D should be given to the newborn. Folic acid is not necessary for newborns.

We refer to the American Academy of Pediatrics website for help. All breastfed newborns should receive a vitamin D supplement of 400 IU per day starting from the first few days of life and continuing until the infant is weaned and consumes adequate amounts of vitamin D-fortified formula or milk. Infants who are exclusively breastfed and who do not receive vitamin D supplementation are at increased risk of vitamin D deficiency, which can lead to rickets and other health problems. Vitamin K is also important to prevent bleeding disorders and is routinely given to newborns. Formula-fed infants receive adequate vitamin K from formula, but breastfed infants should receive a single dose of vitamin K at birth or within the first week of life. Folic acid is not routinely given to newborns but is important for pregnant women to take to reduce the risk of birth defects. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Vitamin K and Vitamin D.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breast milk, while an excellent source of nutrition for newborns, may not have sufficient amounts of vitamin K and vitamin D. Vitamin K helps prevent bleeding disorders in newborns, and vitamin D is important for bone health and development. Therefore, it is recommended that newborns receive both vitamin K and vitamin D supplements, especially if they are not receiving routine medical care. Folic acid is not needed for newborns as it is important for prenatal development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breast milk alone may not provide enough vitamin K and D for a newborn, so both should be given as supplements. Folic acid is important for prenatal care and is not necessary for a newborn who is being breast-fed.
